page.title: 05B'NESS/SOLWAY.HISTORY 1603-.
page.content: St.Michael's church still houses stolen Scottish bells, taken in reprisal for its own, lost in the Firth by raiders. The dangerous crossing of Bowness Wath on foot, by horse or by coach, was succeeded by the Solway Junction Railway's Viaduct (1869). Twice damaged by ice, it took freight and passengers in and out of Scotland until 1921, & was demolished as unsafe 1934/5.{PORT CARLISLE}1 mile East of Bowness was anciently Fisher's Cross, a hamlet comprising only 2 dwellings prior to 1819:Kirkland House (farm) and The Binnacle, built as an Inn. By 1823 a canal and harbour were built to serve Carlisle City. A branch of North British Railway succeeded the canal(1854). Fading trade, silted harbour and low viaduct all caused the decline of the port in the early 19C.
